ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Introduction to art and architecture in the Indian subcontinent
I learned about South Asian architecture, and the history behind the architecture.
We got an overview of South Asian Buddhist, Hindu, and Islamic sacred architecture, as well as some secular buildings, Mughal paintings, and colonial British images of Indian architecture.

I learned a lot about the history, religion, art, and architecture of South Asia. The course is divided into several sections about each of the major religions in South Asia, and explores not only the sacred spaces themselves but also their significance in history and culture.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: interesting lectures and material
Weaknesses: the first paper and midterm project weren't related to South Asia at all, which was a little odd.

The strengths of the course was that it was very comprehensive and engaging. The material was fascinating to learn, and the assignments challenged students' thinking while still being fun to do. 
There were no weaknesses of the course.

The material and teaching style of this class are its main strength, as they are very engaging. I wouldn't say that there are any significant weaknesses to the course other than the fact that it is hard to know how you are doing in the course until the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The live virtual format was helpful for being able to analyze objects up close (digitally). Additionally, the smaller size of the class allowed for a lot of engagement, and I was able to ask questions and better learn the material.
I think that the discussion portions of the course were very helpful for class engagement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Fascinating lectures with lots of amazing pictures!
Yes! Especially if you have no background in South Asia. I found that learning about the architecture and visual imagery provided me a great introduction to Hinduism, for example.

I would definitely recommend this course if you are at least a little bit interested in South Asia or architecture. The course is very accessible to those who are not art history majors. Though the course is technically in lecture format, the small class size allows for a lot of discussion. I was initially worried that I might get bored with the subject before I decided to take this course, but soon found that there is a lot of interesting material to cover.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This course consisted of virtual lectures with discussion included towards the end of class. A few classes were also devoted entirely to discussion of readings or research.

extras.title:
HSAR 383 01/SAST 374 01
        Sacred Space in South Asia
